oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Women; Infants

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Family making rugs
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Handicraft; Weaving; Rugs; Families; Living Rooms; Fireplaces; Older people; Cats; Children; Domestic life
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A family scene of a group making rugs in Hamilton County, Tennessee. A cat laps milk at center, a man sits in a chair cutting pantyhose, a woman creates a rug, and a young girl winds the hose into a ball. A fan made of feathers hangs next to the fireplace. A bowl of popcorn sits on a side table.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: George McCarter creating hand-made baskets
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Country life; Basket making; Older people; Handicraft; Men
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An older man is pictured weaving baskets outside of his workshop. Completed baskets can be seen as well as tools and extra wood. George McCarter was a noted basket weaver.
George McCarter
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Department of Conservation Photograph Collection, 1937-1976
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Basket making was an important arts & crafts tradition of the Appalachian region in East Tennessee. They were traditionally used for gathering eggs or carrying vegetables to the market.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Country life; Stores & shops; Barter; Trucks

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A Depression-era throwback to the barter economy, "rolling stores" allowed country housewives to trade eggs and chickens for groceries.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: J. R. Hull & Alvin C. York
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Veterans; Men

oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Department of Conservation Photograph Collection, 1937-1976
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Alvin Cullum York is a Congressional Medal of Honor winner and hero of World War I, was born in Pall Mall, Fentress County, Tennessee.
